results.title: Mac's mill
results.creator_credit: Gary Toole, ONF | NFB and Bob Nichol
results.brief_description: Mac Armstrong of Warweig, New Brunswick, single handedly runs a water-powered sawmill built back in 1909. While focussing on Mac and his mill, the film touches on other issues such as balanced economy and the intelligent use of natural resources. The film also proves that what worked half a century ago can work today and yield a decent livelihood.

results.title: Maborosi = Maborosi no hikari
results.creator_credit: Naoe Gozu, TV Man Union, Kore-eda and Hirokazu Koreeda
results.brief_description: Makikio Esumi plays a young wife and mother in Tokyo whose husband inexplicably commits suicide. Eventually remarrying, she moves from her cramped working class environment in Tokyo to live with her new husband in a remote fishing village on the coast. Scarred by the devastating effects of her first husband’s death, she finds herself fearful of committing fully to her new relationship, anxious that her very presence brings ill fortune and death. This astounding debut film is a profoundly spiritual examination of the nature of grief and acceptance. Dialogue is pared down to a minimum; instead the camera observes its characters framed against the contrasting urban sprawl of Tokyo and the windswept coast of rural Japan. The meditative and richly poetic mise-en-scene explores the importance of environment, nature and landscape in defining a person’s relationship to the world. Recalling the films of Japan’s celebrated director Ozu, “Maborosi” is a deeply affecting and richly rewarding art film which reaffirms that cinema too can be a place for the creation of transcendental and spiritual works that assist in defining that complex, ambiguous phenomena which is the human condition.

results.title: Mabo: the native title revolution (A)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Buona Notte Productions, Tantamount Productions, Cristina Pozzan, Rob Wellington and Trevor Graham
results.brief_description:
An extensive multimedia resource that explores a pivotal moment in Australian history—the landmark Mabo legal case in which the High Court acknowledged the claim of Aboriginal Australians to native title. Combining 2 CD ROM’s with a website and online database, the project brings together a documentary video with hundreds of specially created audio-visual sequences and a wealth of text and images covering issues from colonisation and indigenous culture to land rights and native title. Suitable for senior secondary, undergraduate and research at adult levels. A website has been created as part of this project containing updates, additional material, technical information and links to other related sites. Available online at www.MaboNativeTitle.com Study notes and related material can be printed from the Film Australia website at http://www.filmast.com.au

results.title: Mabo: the life of an Island man (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Denise Haslem, Film Australia and Trevor Graham
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Trevor Graham documented the only film record of the Mabo proceedings in 1989 in his film “Land Bilong islanders” and in the process established a friendship with Eddie Koiki Mabo. This film documents the extraordinary life of a man so passionate about his family and home that he fought an entire nation and its legal system. Sadly, he died five months before the High Court upheld his claim for “Native Title”. However he cemented a place in Australia’s history. This documentary won an AFI award in 1997.

results.title: Mabo myths
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Best of Lateline”.
The High Court’s Mabo decision late in 1992 was probably the most significant legal decision ever made by an Australian Court. Sadly, it led to widespread scaremongering by sections of the community, the emergence of the ‘Mabo Myths’ and put Aboriginal spokespeople firmly on the back foot. Lateline carefully examines the myths related to the security of various types of land title in Australia and as one observor said, admirably clarifies the decision and its meaning for all Australians.

results.title: Ma Nuit Chez Maud = My Night with Maud
results.creator_credit: Pierre Cotrell, Barbet Schroeder and Eric Rohmer
results.brief_description:
Jean Louis, a Catholic engineer smug in his acceptance of a Pascalian wager about faith, finds his beliefs challenged by an encounter with Maud, a free-thinking divorcee. She represents desire while Francoise - who he has observed from a distance at Mass - seems to represent, for him, a path to the attainment of grace. The ambiguous conflict between instinct and reason, nature and culture is worked through in this sharply observed comedy of manners, the third of Rohmer’s ‘Moral Tales’ (filmed out of sequence) and set in a wintry Clermont-Ferrand. Although there are many ironic moments, Rohmer’s refusal to displace ambiguity with irony allows space for the viewer to find his/her own way through the thicket created between what is observed and the rationalisation of the narrator. Awards: Prix Georges Melies 1969.

Credits: Producers, Barbet Schroeder, Pierre Cotrell ; director, Eric Rohmer ; writer, Eric Rohmer ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; camera assistant, Philippe Rousselot ; editor, Cecile Decugis.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Francoise Fabian, Marie-Christine Barrault, Antoine Vitez.

results.title: Ma Femme Est Formidable = My Wife Is Wonderful
results.brief_description:
Condemned without evidence as a ‘rake’ by his dimwitted wife Sylvia and his monstrous in-laws, Raymond Corbier is further bedeviled by the unwarranted advances of man-chasing Marguerite Rival.

results.title: M. Butterfly [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Gabriella Martinelli, Geffen Pictures and David Cronenberg
results.brief_description: Inspired by a true story and based on David Henry Hwang’s award-winning stage play, this film version by David Cronenberg (Naked lunch, Dead ringers) does not quite live up to expectations even though Hwang has written the screenplay. Set in Beijing, in 1964, the story revolves around married French diplomat Rene Gallimard and his obsessive love affair with Beijing Opera star Song Liling who first entranced Gallimard with her performance as Madama Butterfly. As Gallimard becomes more deeply involved with the secretive and allusive Song Liling, life begins to take an unexpected turn - one that involves intrigue, espionage, and betrayal. Starring Jeremy Irons, John Lone, Barbara Sukowa, Annabel Leventon, Shizuko Hoshi, Ian Richardson.
